speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.2: High School Renovation Project - The board will consider approval of funding for major facility improvements at the high school, including building four new science laboratories and repairing the athletic fields. The science lab construction is projected to cost $1,240,400 spread over four years, while athletic field repairs are included in the same package. These upgrades aim to improve STEM instruction and student access to safe extracurricular facilities.. Who would like to start?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I can start. I've had several meetings with stakeholders involved here, from students to staff members.  We have some serious problems going on, we need some real commitments to the well-being and safety of our kids. Science education nowadays calls for modernized spaces - you all know how rapidly this subject matter changes. But it is simply out of date. You walk into those labs, and they could easily have been classrooms decades ago. I do not feel confident we're giving these kids the very best opportunities available to explore, let alone keep pace with state-of-the-art research.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I agree with Kate, our current science labs are in dire need of an upgrade. As a former teacher myself, I've seen firsthand how outdated equipment and facilities can hinder student engagement and learning outcomes. I'd like to ask, has there been any consideration given to incorporating sustainable and eco-friendly design elements into the new lab construction? Not only would this align with our district's commitment to environmental stewardship, but it could also provide valuable hands-on learning experiences for our students. Has anyone looked into potential grant opportunities or partnerships that might help offset the costs of such features?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yes. One thing I did want to say though, since we're already talking about sustainability. In that study session where we talked about green roofs, one point that was made by the presenter then is even small scale applications of green roofs can make quite an impact on rainwater runoff and so forth, and that just seems relevant with the athletic field work because when we're doing stuff on that end of campus especially, there'll be the storm water management plan anyway.

speaker: davidoberg
content: While I think all the points raised so far have some merit, my primary concern is actually looking down the road - when we are committing to spending a little more than a million dollars on the science labs specifically. That figure may not stay static after this point in time; we could possibly see overages or new challenges. And when I look further ahead, in four years are we prepared then to take on maintenance responsibilities, the upkeep expenses down the line for these state-of-the-art science labs once we've built them? That certainly needs to factor into the overall thinking and planning process.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thanks Dave. I'm right now going through budgetary documents. It doesn't seem like we're necessarily taking funds away from existing programs, right now. So that makes me feel a bit better about supporting that project on the whole. That being said, I'm not particularly sure if there's room to go back and renegotiate contracts. Could we request some specific examples of that scope of work? If it's a certain number of square feet of roofing material and what the projected savings might be so that we're making smart choices, it goes without saying that we should pursue energy efficiencies in all ways possible whenever opportunities arise.

speaker: davidoberg
content: I appreciate Jon's willingness to dig deeper on this. To echo Ellen's point earlier, if we can build in long-term savings via energy-efficient materials and practices while staying within budgetary parameters, that could free up funds later for other priorities. What data do we currently possess regarding the life-cycle maintenance and operating expenditures associated with these improved laboratory spaces as well as upgraded athletic facilities, in total contrast to their present states? That information ought to inform how the Board evaluates this project and potential alternatives, and I agree strongly with asking contractors for detailed breakdowns so we can optimize that trade-off between initial investment and ongoing costs and benefits.

speaker: judyle
content: Thank you, Chair. I'd like to piggyback off Ellen's idea about sustainable design elements. As we renovate the science labs and athletic fields, it's crucial we prioritize accessibility and inclusivity for all students. Have we explored ways to incorporate universal design principles into the renovation plans, ensuring equal participation opportunities for students with disabilities? This would send a powerful message that we value every student's ability to fully engage in STEM education and extracurricular activities.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank goodness Judy highlighted the accessibility aspect. I had it scribbled somewhere in notes too - universal design. I remember seeing that in another presentation on some model schools, how accessible pathways in athletic areas opened up participation from special needs athletes - incredible to behold! Inclusivity considerations really must be central. Does anyone recall what percentage of our students deal with physical impairments? If we put all those numbers together, maybe we'd push that into part of the planning conversations with the architects. I mean, we're not merely focusing on updating these spaces; we're reshaping the experience here for every single kid in this community.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I completely agree with Judy and Kate on the importance of incorporating universal design principles into the renovation plans. Accessibility and inclusivity must be prioritized to ensure that all students have equal opportunities to participate in STEM education and extracurricular activities. I would like to propose that we invite experts in accessible design to consult on the project and provide guidance on how to create inclusive spaces that cater to diverse needs. Additionally, I suggest we allocate a portion of the budget to conduct a thorough assessment of our current infrastructure and identify areas where accessibility improvements can be made beyond the scope of this project. By doing so, we can create a comprehensive plan to enhance the overall accessibility of our school facilities.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I would love to know why are we having to bond, why are we choosing to do this way, because when I saw that price tag, I knew we would have no choice but pay. It appears we would save approximately $200,000 for the school system if we paid cash, which I guess isn't feasible. Would someone clarify why we don't find ways to cut spending elsewhere in favor of paying for school renovations outright rather than borrowing? Can we talk about how our decision impacts the taxpayers directly? Is our approach more strategic now considering everything that's happening with the interest rates that are going to change drastically starting next year? I still find difficulty grappling with how it'll affect our future financial positions. Is it worth taking on debt while facing

speaker: davidoberg
content: Katrina, while your points raise valid concerns, using cash instead of bonds means we'd likely delay important projects like these science labs and athletic field upgrades until money becomes available. Our students deserve timely access to modern resources and facilities that support their development. Interest rates may rise, indeed, but consider how delaying our investment will lead to higher prices over time due to inflation. It is essential to weigh potential cost savings against the potential long-term benefits to our students.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: The last comment seemed overly critical, so I apologize if that came across wrong. Going back to something earlier, I mentioned how we are adding on items because they were things people wanted during the study sessions and committee meetings. But I truly believe we should separate them and at least discuss them individually rather than bundling all together. There's no issue personally with each project on their own, and I think bundling does disservice to the individual items because they get overshadowed. So we could definitely bring up the turf separately, discuss pros and cons of that in isolation. Then when doing the high school parking lot, that has its own merits. Separating them into different proposals makes each more palpable. They're just being packaged up to kind of

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: For the record, I do not have much trouble with separating them out as Katrina indicated earlier. When I hear Dave's perspective about bundling as you could potentially be passing up long-term gains - I grasp it, but also understand where Katrina is coming from. We need clarity on whether individual components make sense outside of the whole package. Let's table any final decisions on this bundle tonight.

speaker: judyle
content: I understand Katrina's concerns about breaking down the proposal into individual components. I think that's a great idea. It would allow us to thoroughly examine each project's merits and assess their priority level. However, we must also acknowledge that bundling these projects together might facilitate more significant cost savings and streamline the construction process. Perhaps we could ask the administration to provide a detailed breakdown of the costs and benefits associated with both approaches, so we can make an informed decision. This would help us strike a balance between fiscal responsibility and providing our students with the facilities they need to succeed.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Could Kate and Judy team up and see whether we already possess documents detailing costs of past projects so that we could make a comparison of bundled versus non-bundled work processes and give better-informed input? Maybe they have even done some scenario-planning with varying cost structures, timelines, or both to gauge viability under differing conditions.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I think Judy and Kate's suggestion is excellent. Having a clear breakdown of the costs and benefits of bundling versus unbundling the projects would allow us to make a more informed decision. I'd like to propose that we request the administration to provide us with a detailed report outlining the pros and cons of each approach, including any potential cost savings, timeline implications, and logistical advantages. Additionally, if we do decide to unbundle the projects, we should establish a clear priority list to ensure that we're allocating our resources effectively and addressing the most pressing needs of our students and staff. By taking a methodical and data-driven approach, we can ensure that we're making the best possible decision for our school community.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Okay, that would be helpful for me at least to try to understand the full picture, though they might not be applicable entirely as I realize. It's a difficult thing. I always feel terrible as I'm trying to advocate for fiscal responsibility but then see the faces of those children at that presentation. It does weigh heavy on my heart.

speaker: davidoberg
content: I appreciate your willingness to dig deeper into specifics, and our district's experience is unique. With bundled projects, you can secure better pricing from contractors who benefit from the scale of work. Now it's true, separating the projects does allow discussion around specific priorities, yet there is also value in packaging these improvements, considering it streamlines efforts and reduces overhead. A clear breakdown of costs would be crucial before deciding.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I think we have consensus in separating the projects for further analysis before making any decision. As suggested, could we get information from administrators on each bundled component's merit compared with standalone projects, along with projected long-term cost savings for this bundling, perhaps by January 12th to factor into any future votes.

speaker: judyle
content: I'd like to emphasize that understanding the cost-benefit analysis of bundled versus unbundled projects is crucial in our decision-making process. Kate and I can work together to gather historical data and documents related to past projects to inform our discussion. Moreover, I agree with Ellen's proposal to request a detailed report from the administration outlining the pros and cons of each approach. By doing so, we can evaluate the viability of both options and prioritize our resources effectively. I also want to acknowledge Katrina's concerns about advocating for fiscal responsibility while keeping the interests of our students in mind. Our goal is to make a well-rounded decision that balances our financial obligations with the needs of our school community.

speaker: kateacuff
content: If I can summarize what was proposed, our two action items, one for Judy and me, is to look at costs for past projects and see if they could compare costs if they were bundled. Number two, the administration should supply a report by the twelfth looking at bundled and unbundled projects and providing the details to guide our decision-making.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I'd like to reiterate that having a clear and comprehensive report from the administration will be instrumental in helping us make an informed decision. I think it's great that Judy and Kate are willing to dive into our past projects' costs and compare them to potential bundled scenarios. In addition to the report, I'd like to request that the administration also provides some insight into any potential risks or challenges associated with either approach. By considering both the financial and operational implications, we can ensure that we're making a well-rounded decision that benefits our school community in the long run.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I think I could support that as well. However, I don't know how we'd come up with those figures without them being provided to us. I guess you're saying, like, a rough estimate, I imagine, of each project separately, to figure out which ones take higher precedence when you look at them on an individual basis. So if it helps clarify, my preference - which again wasn't strongly held - was initially presented the other day about getting the most bang for my buck, essentially, and it was to focus on what provides the most for each kid for a set budget amount we're gonna spend anyway. But the bundling issue may supersede all of those considerations based upon what I've heard here today.

speaker: davidoberg
content: I believe we achieved consensus on examining the projects separately before making a final call. The administrative request should clarify this bundling's financial benefits over unbundled projects by the 12th, allowing us to factor it into subsequent decisions.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: At this point in time, I think everybody agrees. We need this information for informed decisions going forward.

content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.2: Should the board approve funding of $1,240,400 over four years for new science labs, along with athletic field repairs at the high school?.
